yoruba: Ojú ò rọ́lá rí; ó bímọ ẹ̀ ó sọ ọ́ ní Ọláníyọnu.
gold: A person only newly acquainted with wealth; he has a son and names him Ọlaniyọnu.
gen:
Yoruba: Ojú ò rọ́lá rí; ó bímọ ẹ̀ ó sọ ọ́ ní Ọláníyọnu.
English: The eye has never seen wealth; it has a child and names it "Wealth has entered my mouth."

yoruba: Ìwọ̀n eku nìwọ̀n ìtẹ́; olongo kì í gbé tìmùtìmù.
gold: The measure of the rat is the measure of the nest; a robin does not live on a cushion.
gen:
Yoruba: Ìwọ̀n eku nìwọ̀n ìtẹ́; olongo kì í gbé tìmùtìmù.
English: The size of the rat determines the size of the trap; a cat doesn't catch what is too small.

yoruba: Ẹyẹ tó fi ara wé igún, ẹ̀hìn àdìrò ní ńsùn.
gold: Whatever bird emulates the vulture will find itself behind the cooking hearth.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹyẹ tó fi ara wé igún, ẹ̀hìn àdìrò ní ńsùn.
English: The bird that compares itself to a vulture ends up sleeping behind a parrot.

(This proverb suggests that those who overestimate themselves or try to imitate those more powerful/significant will end up in a lesser position than they expect.)

yoruba: Àwúrèbeé ní òún lè yẹ̀nà; ta ní jẹ́ tọ ọ̀nà àwúrèbe?
gold: Àwúrebe says it can make a path; who would wish to follow a path it makes?
gen:
Yoruba: Àwúrèbeé ní òún lè yẹ̀nà; ta ní jẹ́ tọ ọ̀nà àwúrèbe?
English: The "àwúrèbe" (a type of insect/bug) claims it can clear the path; who would follow the path of an àwúrèbe?

(This proverb seems to suggest that one should be cautious about following the leadership or guidance of someone insignificant or incapable, despite their boasts.)

yoruba: Má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ oníle, má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àlejò; lọ́wọ́ ara ẹni la ti ńtẹ́.
gold: Save face with members of your household and save face with complete strangers, such a person loses face with himself/herself.
gen:
Yoruba: Má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ oníle, má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àlejò; lọ́wọ́ ara ẹni la ti ńtẹ́.

English: Don't depend on the homeowner, don't depend on the visitor; one must depend on oneself.

yoruba: Eégún ju eégún; òrìṣá ju òrìṣà; Pààká lé oníṣàngó wọ̀gbẹ́.
gold: Some masqueraders are greater than others; some gods are greater than others; the masquerader Pààká chases the Ṣàngó worshipper into the bush.
gen:
Yoruba: Eégún ju eégún; òrìṣá ju òrìṣà; Pààká lé oníṣàngó wọ̀gbẹ́.
English: Masquerade surpasses masquerade; deity surpasses deity; the Leopard chases the devotee of Sango into the bush.

yoruba: “Mo yó” ńjẹ́ “mo yó,” “mo kọ̀” ńjẹ́ “mo kọ̀”; jẹun ǹṣó, àgbà ọ̀kánjúwà ni.
gold: “I am full” means “I am full”; “I decline” means “I decline”; eating with abandon, that is the father of all greediness.
gen:
Yoruba: "Mo yó" ńjẹ́ "mo yó," "mo kọ̀" ńjẹ́ "mo kọ̀"; jẹun ǹṣó, àgbà ọ̀kánjúwà ni.
English: "I am full" means "I am full," "I refuse" means "I refuse"; to eat and keep staring (for more) is the behavior of a greedy elder.

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà kì í wẹwọ́ tán kó ní òun ó jẹ si.
gold: An elder does not wash his hand and then decide to eat more.
gen:
Yoruba: Àgbàlagbà kì í wẹwọ́ tán kó ní òun ó jẹ si.
English: An elder does not wash his hands and then say he will eat more.

(This proverb suggests that when elders prepare for something specific by taking appropriate measures, they follow through with their original intention rather than changing their minds afterward.)

yoruba: Ẹni à bá tà ká fowó-o rẹ̀ ra àdá: ó ní ìyà àdá ńjẹ òun.
gold: A person who should be sold for money to purchase a machete bemoans his lack of a machete.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Ẹni à bá tà ká fowó-o rẹ̀ ra àdá: ó ní ìyà àdá ńjẹ òun" translates to English as:

"The person who is sold and whose money is used to buy a machete: he says the machete is making him suffer."

This proverb refers to someone who is doubly victimized - first by being sold (as in slavery), and then the proceeds are used to buy a tool (machete) that causes them further suffering. It speaks to the irony of compounded injustice or exploitation.

yoruba: Kàkà ká dọ̀bálẹ̀ fún Gàm̀bàrí, ká rọ́jú ká kú.
gold: Rather than prostrate oneself in homage or obeisance to a Hausa person, one should rather die.
gen:
Yoruba: Kàkà ká dọ̀bálẹ̀ fún Gàm̀bàrí, ká rọ́jú ká kú.
English: Rather than prostrate to a Northerner, it is better to be steadfast and die.

yoruba: À-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa ẹmọ́n; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa àfè; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa máláàjú.
gold: Feeding-without-leaving kills the Tullberg's rat; feeding-without-departing kills the spotted grass mouse; feeding-without-departing kills the máláàjú rat.
gen:
Yoruba: À-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa ẹmọ́n; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa àfè; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa máláàjú.

English: Persistence is what kills the mosquito; persistence is what kills the gnats; persistence is what kills the housefly.

(This proverb emphasizes that persistence or continuing effort is what overcomes challenges - literally saying that it's the consistent, unrelenting effort that eventually defeats even small but persistent pests.)

yoruba: A kì í fi ìka ro etí, ká fi ro imú, ká wá tún fi ta ehín.
gold: One does not use one's finger to clean one's ear passages, use it to pick one's nose, and then use it to pick one's teeth.
gen:
Yoruba: A kì í fi ìka ro etí, ká fi ro imú, ká wá tún fi ta ehín.
English: One does not use the same finger to clean the ear, then the nose, and then pick the teeth.

yoruba: Ṣàkì ńṣe bí ọ̀rá, egungun ńṣe bí ẹran.
gold: The tripe presents itself as fat; the bone presents itself as meat.
gen:
Yoruba: Ṣàkì ńṣe bí ọ̀rá, egungun ńṣe bí ẹran.
English: Saki (a type of monkey) pretends to be like a wildcat, bones pretend to be like meat.

yoruba: Ọ̀yájú-u baálé ní ńpàdé ìbòsí lọ́nà.
gold: It is a reckless home owner who is met with alarms when he ventures outside.
gen:
Yoruba: Ọ̀yájú-u baálé ní ńpàdé ìbòsí lọ́nà.
English: It is the impatient head of household who encounters feces on the road.

(This proverb suggests that rushing or being hasty often leads to unpleasant consequences or embarrassment. Someone who acts without proper patience or consideration may end up in an unfortunate situation.)

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà tí ò kí Ààrẹ ńfi okùn sin ara-a rẹ̀.
gold: An elder who does not greet the Ààrẹ tries a “hanging” rope for size.
gen:
Yoruba: Àgbàlagbà tí ò kí Ààrẹ ńfi okùn sin ara-a rẹ̀.
English: An elder who does not greet the Aare (chief/warrior) is preparing a rope for his own funeral.

This proverb suggests that an elder who fails to show proper respect to authority (the Aare) is bringing trouble upon himself - essentially digging his own grave or preparing for his own demise.

yoruba: Àì-lápá làdá ò mú; bí a bá lápá, ọmọ owú to-o gégi.
gold: It is a deficiency of biceps that blunts the machete; if one has strong biceps one can cut trees with a cudgel.
gen:
Yoruba: Àì-lápá làdá ò mú; bí a bá lápá, ọmọ owú to-o gégi.
English: It is lack of strength that makes a machete ineffective; if one has strength, even a cotton thread can cut a tree.

yoruba: Ibi tí a fi ara sí lara ńgbé.
gold: Wherever one situates the body, there it inhabits.
gen:
Yoruba: Ibi tí a fi ara sí lara ńgbé.
English: Where we place ourselves is where the body dwells.

This proverb suggests that we find ourselves in the situations or places we choose to be, or that one's circumstances reflect one's choices and efforts.

yoruba: Bí ìlàrí bá fẹ́ tẹ́, a ní kí lọba ó ṣe?
gold: When a courtier seeks disgrace, he asks, “What can the king do?”
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Bí ìlàrí bá fẹ́ tẹ́, a ní kí lọba ó ṣe?" translates to English as:

"When the palace servant wants to rebel, he asks what the king has done wrong."

This proverb refers to someone who is looking for excuses to justify their misconduct or rebellion, specifically by trying to shift blame onto authority figures.

yoruba: Àfi ohun tí a kì í tà lọ́jà lẹrú kì í jẹ.
gold: The only thing a slave cannot eat is something not available in the market.
gen:
Yoruba: Àfi ohun tí a kì í tà lọ́jà lẹrú kì í jẹ.
English: Only what is not sold in the market will a slave not eat.

This proverb suggests that slaves are restricted to eating only what their masters provide them, meaning they have limited choices and must accept whatever is available to them. It speaks to the constraints of those in subordinate positions who cannot exercise freedom of choice.

yoruba: Àṣá kì í rà kádìẹ gbé kòkòrò dání.
gold: When a kite hovers, a chicken does not hang on to an insect.
gen:
Yoruba: Àṣá kì í rà kádìẹ gbé kòkòrò dání.
English: The hawk does not catch a chicken to feed insects.

(This proverb suggests that people don't go to great efforts for someone else's benefit - a powerful entity doesn't expend energy to benefit lesser beings or others.)

yoruba: Ká wí ogún, ká wí ọgbọ̀n, “Ng ò fẹ́, ng ò gbà” laṣiwèré fi ńpẹ̀kun ọ̀ràn.
gold: Whether one speaks twenty times or speaks thirty times, “I do not like it, and I will not accept it” is how the imbecile ends the discussion.
gen:
Yoruba: Ká wí ogún, ká wí ọgbọ̀n, "Ng ò fẹ́, ng ò gbà" laṣiwèré fi ńpẹ̀kun ọ̀ràn.
English: We may speak twenty times, we may speak thirty times, but "I don't want it, I won't accept it" is how a fool ends a matter.

yoruba: Ẹni tí a fẹ́ yàtọ̀ sí ẹni tó ní kò sí irú òun.
gold: A person one loves is different from a person who says there is no one like him/herself.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹni tí a fẹ́ yàtọ̀ sí ẹni tó ní kò sí irú òun.
English: The person one loves is different from the one who says there's none like them.

This proverb contrasts the person who is genuinely loved with someone who boasts about their uniqueness or incomparability.

yoruba: Àgùnbánirọ̀ ní ńfojúdini.
gold: It is the person taller than another who shows no respect for the other.
gen:
Yoruba: Àgùnbánirọ̀ ní ńfojúdini.
English: A hypocrite is the one who deceives you to your face.

yoruba: Ìtàkùn tó tó ọ̀pẹ kò tó pé kérin má lọ; ìtàkùn tó pé kérin má lọ Àlọ́, tòun terin ní ńlọ.
gold: A vine as thick as a palm-tree trunk will not stop an elephant; whatever vine attempts to stop an elephant from going to Alọ will go with the elephant instead.
gen:
Yoruba: Ìtàkùn tó tó ọ̀pẹ kò tó pé kérin má lọ; ìtàkùn tó pé kérin má lọ Àlọ́, tòun terin ní ńlọ.
English: The creeper that is as tall as a palm tree is not enough to stop an elephant from passing; the creeper that claims it can stop an elephant from passing, Alo, will end up going along with the elephant.

yoruba: Bí a bá ńgúnyán, kòmẹsẹ̀ á yọ.
gold: If one prepares pounded yams, the uninvited should depart.
gen:
Yoruba: Bí a bá ńgúnyán, kòmẹsẹ̀ á yọ.
English: When pounded yam is being eaten, the thumb will emerge.

This proverb suggests that certain situations inevitably reveal particular outcomes or truths. Just as the thumb necessarily becomes visible when eating pounded yam (as it's typically eaten with the hands), some things cannot remain hidden during certain activities.

yoruba: Ọmọ àì-jọbẹ̀-rí tí ńja epo sáyà.
gold: A child new to eating stews: he shows himself by dripping palm-oil on his chest.
gen:
Yoruba: Ọmọ àì-jọbẹ̀-rí tí ńja epo sáyà.
English: A child who has never seen soup before is storing up palm oil in his chest.

This proverb is commenting on someone who acts inappropriately or wastefully because they lack experience or knowledge. Just as a child who has never seen proper soup might misuse valuable palm oil (by storing it on their chest rather than using it correctly in cooking), so too might inexperienced people mishandle valuable resources or opportunities due to their ignorance.

yoruba: Kì í dọwọ́-ọ baba kó ló di ọwọ́ ọmọ.
gold: Responsibility does not devolve on the father only for him to say it is his son's duty.
gen:
Yoruba: Kì í dọwọ́-ọ baba kó ló di ọwọ́ ọmọ.
English: What is in the father's hand does not easily pass to the child's hand.

This proverb suggests that wealth, power, or possessions that belong to the father (or older generation) aren't automatically or easily transferred to the child (or younger generation). It implies that inheritance or succession involves more than just simple handover, and that the younger generation may need to earn or work for what the older generation has.

yoruba: Ó yẹ ẹni gbogbo kó dínwó aró, kò yẹ atọ̀ọ́lé.
gold: It is fitting for everybody to bargain to reduce the cost of dyeing clothes, but not the bed wetter.
gen:
Yoruba: Ó yẹ ẹni gbogbo kó dínwó aró, kò yẹ atọ̀ọ́lé.
English: It is proper for everyone to reduce the blue dye expenses, but not proper for the head of the house.

yoruba: Ìbàjẹ́ ọjọ́ kan ò tán bọ̀rọ̀.
gold: The disgrace one incurs in one day does not disappear that soon.
gen:
English: The damage of one day does not end quickly/easily.

This Yoruba proverb suggests that the consequences of a single day's misfortune or bad actions can have lasting effects that aren't quickly resolved. It conveys the idea that negative impacts can persist long after the initial event.

yoruba: Ibi tí a ti ńpìtàn ká tó jogún, ká mọ̀ pé ogún ibẹ̀ ò kanni.
gold: Where one must recite genealogies in order to establish one's claim to inheritance, one should know that one really has no claim to patrimony there.
gen:
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ti ńpìtàn ká tó jogún, ká mọ̀ pé ogún ibẹ̀ ò kanni.
English: Where we are being told stories before inheriting, we should know that the inheritance there doesn't affect us.

This proverb suggests that if someone has to be told stories or given explanations before receiving an inheritance, they should understand that the inheritance may not truly belong to them or benefit them. It implies that legitimate heirs don't need extensive explanations about what is rightfully theirs.

yoruba: Bí baálẹ̀-ẹ́ bá ńtàkìtì, òrógi là ḿbá ẹmẹsẹ̀.
gold: If the chief is turning somersaults, the messenger should be found standing erect.
gen:
Yoruba: Bí baálẹ̀-ẹ́ bá ńtàkìtì, òrógi là ḿbá ẹmẹsẹ̀.
English: When the landlord is dancing wildly, it is the rafters that meet with the feet.

(This proverb suggests that when a person in authority behaves recklessly or inappropriately, it's often those under them who suffer the consequences.)

yoruba: Afínjú wọ ọjà ó rìn gbẹndẹ́kẹ ọ̀bún wọ ọjà ó rìn ṣùẹ̀ṣùẹ̀; ọ̀bùn ní ó ru ẹrù afínjú relé.
gold: The fashionable person enters the market and walks in a leisurely manner; the filthy person enters the market and walks in a sluggish manner; it is the filthy person that will carry the fashionable person's load to the house for him or her.
gen: English: The fop enters the market walking proudly and stylishly, the filthy person enters the market walking slowly and cautiously; it is the filthy person who carries the fop's load home.

yoruba: Aáyán ati eèràá ṣígun, wọ́n ní àwọ́n ńlọ mú adìẹ àlọ la rí, a ò rábọ̀.
gold: Cockroach and ant make ready for war and say they are off to capture chicken; we see their departure, but not their return.
gen:
Yoruba: Aáyán ati eèràá ṣígun, wọ́n ní àwọ́n ńlọ mú adìẹ àlọ la rí, a ò rábọ̀.
English: The cockroach and the ant went to war, they said they were going to capture chickens but we saw them going, we never saw them return.

yoruba: Ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ ò mẹ̀yẹ.
gold: A pig does not know what is becoming.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ ò mẹ̀yẹ.
English: A pig does not know shame.

This proverb suggests that someone who behaves like a pig (or in a shameless manner) has no sense of embarrassment or propriety about their actions.

yoruba: Ẹ̀wọ̀n tó tó ọ̀pẹ ò tó-ó dá erin dúró; ìtàkùn tó ní kí erin má ròkè ọ̀dàn, tòun terin ní ńlọ.
gold: A chain as thick as a palm-tree cannot stop an elephant; the vine that proposes to stop the elephant from going to the grassland will go with the elephant.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹ̀wọ̀n tó tó ọ̀pẹ ò tó-ó dá erin dúró; ìtàkùn tó ní kí erin má ròkè ọ̀dàn, tòun terin ní ńlọ.
English: A chain that can hold a palm tree cannot stop an elephant; the rope that tells an elephant not to climb a savanna tree will end up going with the elephant.

yoruba: Àfòpiná tó ní òun ó pa fìtílà, ara ẹ̀ ni yó pa.
gold: The moth that attempts to kill (put out) the oil lamp will kill itself.
gen:
Yoruba: Àfòpiná tó ní òun ó pa fìtílà, ara ẹ̀ ni yó pa.
English: The moth that says it will extinguish the lamp will only destroy itself.

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà akàn tó kó sí garawa yègèdè, ojú tì í.
gold: The elderly crab that enters into a bucket; it is thoroughly disgraced.
gen:
Yoruba: Àgbàlagbà akàn tó kó sí garawa yègèdè, ojú tì í.
English: An elderly person who defecates in a basket of bananas feels ashamed.

This proverb expresses that someone of mature age who acts inappropriately or causes embarrassment in a situation should naturally feel shame for their actions, particularly when they should know better given their experience and status.

yoruba: A pè ọ́ lọ́mọ erín-màgbọn ò ńyọ̀; ìwọ pàápàá ló mì í?
gold: You are described as the child of the elephant that swallows coconuts, and you rejoice; are you the one who swallows coconuts?
gen:
Yoruba: A pè ọ́ lọ́mọ erín-màgbọn ò ńyọ̀; ìwọ pàápàá ló mì í?
English: You are called the child of an elephant and you are not proud; are you the one who swallowed it?

yoruba: Olówó ní ḿbá ọlọ́rọ̀-ọ́ rìn; ẹgbẹ́ ní ḿbá ẹgbẹ́ ṣeré.
gold: It is a rich person that keeps company with a wealthy person; only people of equal standing play together.
gen:
Yoruba: Olówó ní ḿbá ọlọ́rọ̀-ọ́ rìn; ẹgbẹ́ ní ḿbá ẹgbẹ́ ṣeré.
English: The wealthy person walks with the rich; peers play with peers.

yoruba: Kí ẹrú mọ ara ẹ̀ lẹ́rú; kí ìwọ̀fà mọ ara ẹ̀ níwọ̀fà; kí ọmọlúwàbí mọ ara ẹ̀ lẹ́rú Ọlọ́run ọba.
gold: Let the slave know him/herself as a slave; let the pawn know him/herself as a pawn; let the well born person know him/herself as the child of God.
gen: English: Let the slave know themselves as a slave; let the indentured servant know themselves as an indentured servant; let the person of good character know themselves as a servant of God the king.

yoruba: A kì í gbọ́n ju ẹni tí a máa dÍfá fún.
gold: One cannot be wiser than the person for whom one will consult the Ifá oracle.
gen:
Yoruba: A kì í gbọ́n ju ẹni tí a máa dÍfá fún.
English: One should not claim to be wiser than the person for whom one is consulting the Ifa oracle.

yoruba: Kí ni wọ́n ti ńṣe Àmọ́dù nÍlọrin? Ewúrẹ́ ńjẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.
gold: What use do the people of Ilorin have for Ahmadu? Even goats are so named.
gen:
Yoruba: Kí ni wọ́n ti ńṣe Àmọ́dù nÍlọrin? Ewúrẹ́ ńjẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.
English: What are they doing to Amodu in Ilorin? The goat continues to eat regardless.

yoruba: A-dá-má-lè-ṣe àdàbà tí ńdún bẹ̀m̀bẹ̀.
gold: Start-something-it-cannot-finish dove that makes bombastic noises.
gen:
Yoruba: A-dá-má-lè-ṣe àdàbà tí ńdún bẹ̀m̀bẹ̀.
English: The one-who-cannot-act (incompetent person) is like a dove that merely coos without action.

This proverb refers to someone who makes noise or promises but cannot deliver on them - similar to a dove that makes cooing sounds but accomplishes nothing substantial.

yoruba: A-lu-dùndún kì í dárin.
gold: The dùndún player does not lead a song.
gen:
Yoruba: A-lu-dùndún kì í dárin.
English: The dùndún drummer does not start the song.

yoruba: Aláṣọ-kan kì í ná ànárẹ.
gold: A person who has only one set of clothing does not bargain until he is wet.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Aláṣọ-kan kì í ná ànárẹ" translates to English as:

"A person with only one cloth cannot spread it out to dry in the sun."

This proverb suggests that someone with limited resources (like having only one piece of clothing) cannot afford to be wasteful or careless with what little they have, as they need to use it continuously.

yoruba: Ọjọ́ àgbà-á kú sàn ju ọjọ́ àgbà-á tẹ́.
gold: The day an elder dies is far better than the day an elder is disgraced.
gen:
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ àgbà-á kú sàn ju ọjọ́ àgbà-á tẹ́.
English: The day an elder dies is better than the day an elder is disgraced.

yoruba: Ẹyẹ ò lè rí omi inú àgbọn bù mu.
gold: A bird cannot get at the liquid inside a coconut to drink.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹyẹ ò lè rí omi inú àgbọn bù mu.
English: A bird cannot drink water from inside a coconut.

yoruba: “Mo mọ̀-ọ́ tán” lOrò-ó fi ńgbé ọkùnrin.
gold: “I know it all” is the reason for Orò's carrying a man away.
gen:
Yoruba: "Mo mọ̀-ọ́ tán" lOrò-ó fi ńgbé ọkùnrin.
English: "I know him completely" is how Oro (deity) carries off a man.

This proverb suggests that overconfidence or the assumption that one fully understands something (or someone) can lead to one's downfall. In Yoruba tradition, Oro is a powerful deity associated with judgment and punishment, so the proverb warns against presuming complete knowledge, as such presumption can lead to unexpected negative consequences.

yoruba: Nígbàtí à ńto ọkà a ò to ti ẹmọ́ si.
gold: When we were stacking the corn we did not stack some for the brown rat.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Nígbàtí à ńto ọkà a ò to ti ẹmọ́ si" translates to English as:

"When we are sifting corn, we do not sift palm kernels at the same time."

This proverb suggests that one should focus on one task at a time rather than trying to do multiple things simultaneously, emphasizing the importance of focus and prioritization.

yoruba: Àbúrò rẹ ńdáṣọ fún ọ, o ní o ò lo elékuru; ta ní ńlo alákàrà?
gold: Your junior brother (or sister) buys clothing for you, and you say you will not wear anything with bean-grits patterns; who has the right to opt for clothing with a bean-fritter patterns?
gen:
English: Your younger sibling is making clothes for you, and you complain that they're not using elékuru (fine fabric); who is wearing alákàrà (coarse fabric)?

This proverb suggests that when someone is doing you a favor (like making clothes), it's ungrateful to complain about the quality. It cautions against being overly critical of gifts or help received, especially when you're not in a position to be choosy. The message is about appreciating what others do for you rather than finding fault with their generosity.

yoruba: Bí kò sí tọ̀bùn èèyàn, ta ni ìbá jí lówùúrọ̀ tí kò bọ́jú ṣáṣá?
gold: But for a person of filthy habits, who would wake in the morning and not wash his or her face clean?
gen:
Yoruba: Bí kò sí tọ̀bùn èèyàn, ta ni ìbá jí lówùúrọ̀ tí kò bọ́jú ṣáṣá?
English: If there were no troublesome people, who would wake up in the morning without washing their eyes properly?

yoruba: Àpọ́nlé ni “İyá-a Káà”; ìyá kan ò sí ní káà tí kò lórúkọ.
gold: Calling a person “Mother of the Compound” is only a mark of respect; there is no mother in the compound who does not have a name.
gen:
Yoruba: Àpọ́nlé ni "İyá-a Káà"; ìyá kan ò sí ní káà tí kò lórúkọ.
English: "Mother of Káà" is an honorific; there is no mother in a clan who does not have a name.

yoruba: Bí iná bá dun ọbẹ̀, a dá ọ̀rọ̀ sọ.
gold: If the fire gets at the stew, the stew will burst into speech.
gen: English: When the fire affects the soup, a conversation is started.

yoruba: Àṣejù baba àṣetẹ́; ẹ̀tẹ́ ní ńgbẹ̀hìn àṣejù; àgbàlagbà tó wẹ̀wù àṣejù ẹ̀tẹ́ ni yó fi rí.
gold: Lack of moderation is the father of disgrace; disgrace comes of immoderation; a grown person who clothes himself in immoderation will find disgrace.
gen: English: Excess is the father of shame; shame is the outcome of excess; an elder who indulges in excess will end up in shame.

yoruba: Ọjọ́ kan ṣoṣo là ńtẹ́; ojoojúmọ́ lojú ńtini.
gold: It takes one day only for one to disgrace oneself; the shame is a daily affair.
gen:
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ kan ṣoṣo là ńtẹ́; ojoojúmọ́ lojú ńtini.
English: It is only one day that we tread (or step on something/someone); it is every day that shame/embarrassment comes to us.

The proverb contrasts a one-time action (stepping on or offending someone) with the lasting shame or consequences that can follow daily. It suggests that while an offense might be committed in just a moment, the repercussions or embarrassment can persist for much longer.

yoruba: A kì í dákẹ́ ká ṣìwí; a kì í wò sùn-ùn ká dáràn.
gold: One does not keep quiet and yet misspeak; one does not silently contemplate the world and yet get into trouble.
gen:
Yoruba: A kì í dákẹ́ ká ṣìwí; a kì í wò sùn-ùn ká dáràn.
English: One should not keep quiet and misspeak; one should not stare blankly and be found guilty.

This proverb essentially means that silence does not mean one agrees with wrongdoing, and mere observation doesn't make one complicit in offense. It's about the importance of speaking up against wrongdoing rather than remaining silent, which could be mistaken for consent or participation.

yoruba: Ṣe bóo ti mọ, ẹlẹ́wàa Ṣàpọ́n.
gold: Moderate your preening and strutting, beautiful woman of Ṣàpọ́n.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Ṣe bóo ti mọ, ẹlẹ́wàa Ṣàpọ́n" translates to English as:

"Do as you know how to, beautiful one of Ṣàpọ́n."

This proverb appears to be acknowledging someone's beauty or skill while encouraging them to act according to their knowledge or abilities.

yoruba: Gbogbo èèyàn ní ńsunkún-un Bánjọ; ṣùgbọ́n Bánjọ ò sunkún ara ẹ̀.
gold: Everybody laments Banjọ's fate, but Banjọ does not lament his own fate.
gen:
Yoruba: Gbogbo èèyàn ní ńsunkún-un Bánjọ; ṣùgbọ́n Bánjọ ò sunkún ara ẹ̀.
English: Everyone is crying for Banjo; but Banjo is not crying for himself.

yoruba: Idà ahun la fi ńpa ahun.
gold: It is with its own sword that one kills the tortoise.
gen:
Yoruba: Idà ahun la fi ńpa ahun.
English: It is with the tortoise's sword that we kill the tortoise.

(This proverb suggests that a person's own weapons or methods can be used against them, or that one's own characteristics or actions can lead to one's downfall.)

yoruba: Oúnjẹ ọmọ kékeré a máa wọ àgbà nínú; òrùka ọmọ kékeré ni kì í wọ ágbá lọ́wọ́.
gold: A youth's food can enter the stomach of an elder; it is only a youth's ring that cannot slip unto an elder's finger.
gen:
Yoruba: Oúnjẹ ọmọ kékeré a máa wọ àgbà nínú; òrùka ọmọ kékeré ni kì í wọ ágbá lọ́wọ́.
English: A child's food can fit into an elder's stomach; but a child's ring cannot fit on an elder's finger.

yoruba: “Ẹ fà á wọlé” ló yẹ ẹlẹ́ṣin.
gold: “Lead it into the stable” is what becomes a horseman.
gen:
Yoruba: "Ẹ fà á wọlé" ló yẹ ẹlẹ́ṣin.
English: "Drag him inside" is what is appropriate for the horseman.

This proverb suggests that a person of importance (the horseman) should be brought in with proper respect or assistance. It speaks to the appropriate way to treat someone of status.

yoruba: Ajá kì í lọ ságinjù lọ ṣọdẹ ẹkùn.
gold: A dog does not go into the wild to hunt a leopard.
gen:
Yoruba: Ajá kì í lọ ságinjù lọ ṣọdẹ ẹkùn.
English: A dog does not go into the deep forest to hunt a leopard.

yoruba: Alátiṣe ní ḿmọ àtiṣe ara-a rẹ̀.
gold: The person who must settle his/her affair knows best how he/she plans to go about doing so.
gen:
Yoruba: Alátiṣe ní ḿmọ àtiṣe ara-a rẹ̀.
English: The person responsible knows how to take care of themselves.

This Yoruba proverb essentially means that those who are responsible or accountable understand their own duties and how to manage their own affairs.

yoruba: Àpárá ńlá, ìjà ní ńdà.
gold: Excessive ribbing unfailingly leads to a fight.
gen:
Yoruba: Àpárá ńlá, ìjà ní ńdà.
English: A big thunderclap foretells a fight/conflict.

yoruba: Òní, ẹtú jìnfìn, ọ̀la, ẹtú jìnfìn; ẹtu nìkan lẹran tó wà nígbó?
gold: Today, the antelope falls into the ditch; tomorrow, the antelope falls into the ditch; is the antelope the only animal in the forest?
gen: English: Today, we hunt antelope, tomorrow, we hunt antelope; is antelope the only animal in the forest?

yoruba: Ìyàwó tó na ọmọ ọbàkan, ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ gbọ́.
gold: The wife who whips a relative of her husband is asking for stern rebuke.
gen:
Yoruba: Ìyàwó tó na ọmọ ọbàkan, ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ gbọ́.
English: A wife who beats her stepchild is looking for trouble.

The proverb suggests that when a woman punishes or mistreats her husband's child from another wife, she is inviting conflict or criticism. It reflects the cultural understanding of complex family dynamics in polygamous or blended family settings.

yoruba: “Ọjọ́ tí mo ti ḿbọ̀ ng ò rírú ẹ̀ rí”: olúwa ẹ̀-ẹ́ mọ ìwọ̀n ara ẹ̀ ni.
gold: “In all the days I have walked this earth I have never seen the like”: that person knows his place.
gen:
Yoruba: "Ọjọ́ tí mo ti ḿbọ̀ ng ò rírú ẹ̀ rí": olúwa ẹ̀-ẹ́ mọ ìwọ̀n ara ẹ̀ ni.
English: "Since I've been worshipping, I've never seen anything like this": the owner knows his own limitations.

yoruba: Àì-kúkú-joye, ó sàn ju, “Ẹnuù mi ò ká ìlú” lọ.
gold: Not-assuming-the-position-of-ruler-at-all is far better than, “My word is not heeded by the people.”
gen:
Yoruba: Àì-kúkú-joye, ó sàn ju, "Ẹnuù mi ò ká ìlú" lọ.
English: Not becoming a chief at all is better than saying, "My authority is not respected by the town."

This proverb suggests that it's better not to hold a position of power at all than to hold one where you have no real authority or respect.

yoruba: À-wín-ná-wó ò yẹni; à-gbà-bọ̀-ọ ṣòkòtò ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn; bí kò fúnni lẹ́sẹ̀ a dòrògí; ohun ẹni ní ńyẹni.
gold: Borrowing-money-to-spend does not speak well of one; borrowed trousers do not become a person; if it is not tight around the legs it is difficult to remove; it is one's thing that fits one.
gen:
Yoruba: À-wín-ná-wó ò yẹni; à-gbà-bọ̀-ọ ṣòkòtò ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn; bí kò fúnni lẹ́sẹ̀ a dòrògí; ohun ẹni ní ńyẹni.
English: Spending money lavishly does not suit one; wearing borrowed trousers does not suit a person; if it doesn't fit your legs, it becomes baggy; only what belongs to you truly suits you.

yoruba: Kí ni Dáàró ní kó tó sọ pé olè-é kó òun?
gold: What did Dáàró own before he claimed he was robbed?
gen:
Yoruba: Kí ni Dáàró ní kó tó sọ pé olè-é kó òun?
English: What did Daaro have before he claimed that he was robbed?

yoruba: Ẹlẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́ ńlọ ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́, o ní “Ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀ta ni àbí ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀fà?”; èwo lo gbé níbẹ̀?
gold: A person says he has lost an unspecified amount of money, and you ask if the amount is five hundred cowries or eleven hundred cowries; which amount did you steal?
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹlẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́ ńlọ ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́, o ní "Ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀ta ni àbí ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀fà?"; èwo lo gbé níbẹ̀?
English: The seller of shrimp is going to sell shrimp, and asks, "Is it five hundred shrimp or six hundred shrimp?"; which one did you take from there?

yoruba: Ojú kì í pọ́n baálé ilé kó fọwọ́ gbálẹ̀ ilé ẹ̀.
gold: A head of a household is never so hard up that he sweeps his compound with his bare hands.
gen:
English: The master of the house's eyes are not so sore that he would sweep his own house with his hands.

This proverb suggests that no matter how difficult things get, the head of a household (or a leader) should not stoop to doing tasks beneath their station or dignity. It implies that even in challenging circumstances, people should maintain proper roles and responsibilities.

yoruba: “Ẹ kú-ulé” ò yẹ ará ilé; “Ẹ kú atìbà” ò yẹni tí ńtàjò bọ̀; ẹni tí ò kí ẹni, “Kú atìbà”-á pàdánù “Ẹ kú-ulé.”
gold: “Greetings to you, house-bound ones” is improper for the house-bound to utter; “Welcome home” is not proper for the person arriving from a trip; whoever fails to give “welcome” to the person returning does himself or herself out of “greetings, house-bound.”
gen:
Yoruba: "Ẹ kú-ulé" ò yẹ ará ilé; "Ẹ kú atìbà" ò yẹni tí ńtàjò bọ̀; ẹni tí ò kí ẹni, "Kú atìbà"-á pàdánù "Ẹ kú-ulé."

English: "Welcome home" is not appropriate for the home dweller; "Welcome visitor" is not appropriate for one returning from a journey; the person who doesn't greet someone with "Welcome visitor" will miss out on receiving "Welcome home."

yoruba: Ẹran kí la ò jẹ rí? Ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ báni lábàtà ó ba búrúbúrú.
gold: What sort of meat is it, the likes of which one has never tasted? A toad comes upon one at the swamp and cowers in fright.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹran kí la ò jẹ rí? Ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ báni lábàtà ó ba búrúbúrú.
English: What meat have we not eaten before? The toad meets us on the road and ruins everything.

yoruba: A-binú-fùfù ní ńwá oúnjẹ fún a-binú-wẹ́rẹ́-wẹ́rẹ́.
gold: A volatile-tempered person secures food for a mild-tempered person.
gen:
English: The one who gets angry in a hurry/rashly provides food for the one who gets angry slowly/deliberately.

This proverb suggests that those who react impulsively with anger often create opportunities or advantages for those who are more patient and calculated in their emotional responses.

yoruba: Pẹ̀tẹ̀pẹ́tẹ̀ Ìjèṣà, ó ta sẹ́ni lára kò wọ́n.
gold: The mud of the Ìjèṣà: it splashes on one and will not be washed off.
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Pẹ̀tẹ̀pẹ́tẹ̀ Ìjèṣà, ó ta sẹ́ni lára kò wọ́n" translates to English as:

"The Ijesha slap/pat, it strikes one's body but it's not painful."

This proverb refers to something that appears threatening but is actually harmless, or something that seems severe but has little impact.

yoruba: Ta ní ńjẹun tájá ńjùrù?
gold: At whose dinner table is the dog wagging its tail?
gen:
Based on the Yoruba proverb you've provided, here's the English translation:

Yoruba: Ta ní ńjẹun tájá ńjùrù?
English: Who is eating while the dog is salivating/drooling?

This proverb appears to refer to a situation where someone is enjoying something (eating) while another (the dog) can only watch and long for it without partaking.

yoruba: Afínjú ní ńjẹ iwọ; ọ̀mọ̀ràn ní ńjẹ obì; màrí-màjẹ ní ńjẹ awùsá.
gold: It is a finicky person that eats iwọ;
gen:
Yoruba: Afínjú ní ńjẹ iwọ; ọ̀mọ̀ràn ní ńjẹ obì; màrí-màjẹ ní ńjẹ awùsá.
English: The elegant person eats palm butter; the wise person eats kola nut; the know-nothing eats awùsá nut.

yoruba: Bí a kò bá tó ìyà-á kọ̀ tí à ńkọ̀ ọ́, àjẹkún ìyà là ńjẹ.
gold: If one lacks the means to reject suffering and attempts to reject it, one's suffering simply multiplies.
gen:
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá tó ìyà-á kọ̀ tí à ńkọ̀ ọ́, àjẹkún ìyà là ńjẹ.
English: If one doesn't have the ability to reject suffering but tries to reject it anyway, one will suffer endlessly.

yoruba: A kì í bọ òrìṣà lójú ọ̀fọ́n-ọ̀n; bó bá dalẹ́ a máa tú pẹpẹ.
gold: One does not sacrifice to a god in the presence of a house rat; otherwise, when night falls it invades the rafter shelves.
gen:
Yoruba: A kì í bọ òrìṣà lójú ọ̀fọ̀n-ọ̀n; bó bá dalẹ́ a máa tú pẹpẹ.
English: One does not worship a deity during a time of scarcity; when abundance comes, the altar will be neglected.

yoruba: Ìwọ̀sí ní
gold: X
gen:
The Yoruba phrase "Ìwọ̀sí ní" would translate to English as:

"It is the left side" or simply "The left side"

In Yoruba, "Ìwọ̀sí" refers to the left side or left direction.

yoruba: Àgbà tí kò lẹ́sẹ̀ nílẹ̀ a lọ́gbọ́n nínú.
gold: An elder that has no substance should have cunning.
gen:
Yoruba: Àgbà tí kò lẹ́sẹ̀ nílẹ̀ a lọ́gbọ́n nínú.
English: An elder who does not have his feet on the ground (who is not stable/grounded) has wisdom inside.

This proverb suggests that even elders who may appear physically unsteady or who lack material stability can still possess great wisdom or intelligence. It emphasizes that wisdom doesn't necessarily correlate with physical capabilities or social standing.

yoruba: À ńjá ìbàǹtẹ́ ẹ̀ lẹ́hìn, ó ńjá tará iwájú.
gold: His loincloth is being stripped from behind, yet he is stripping those of the people ahead of him.
gen:
Yoruba: À ńjá ìbàǹtẹ́ ẹ̀ lẹ́hìn, ó ńjá tará iwájú.
English: We are undoing his waistband from behind, yet he is undoing the one in front.

This proverb speaks to someone working against their own interests or undoing the help others are trying to provide them.

yoruba: Ẹ̀yá ló bí mi, ẹkùn ló wò mí dàgbà, ológìnní gbà mí tọ́; bí kò sẹ́ran lọ́bẹ̀ nkò jẹ.
gold: I was born of a monkey; I was raised by a leopard, I was adopted by a cat; if there is no meat in the stew I will not eat it.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹ̀yá ló bí mi, ẹkùn ló wò mí dàgbà, ológìnní gbà mí tọ́; bí kò sẹ́ran lọ́bẹ̀ nkò jẹ.
English: I was born of a monkey, raised by a leopard, and trained by a cat; if there is no meat in the stew, I will not eat it.

This proverb uses animal imagery to convey someone's particular upbringing or nature that has led to specific tastes or standards. It suggests the person has inherited or developed particular habits or preferences that cannot be easily changed.

yoruba: À-jẹ-tán, à-jẹ-ì-mọra, ká fi ọwọ́ mẹ́wẹ̀ẹ̀wá jẹun ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn.
gold: Eating-absolutely-everything, eating-with-abandon, eating with all ten fingers is unworthy of human beings.
gen:
Yoruba: À-jẹ-tán, à-jẹ-ì-mọra, ká fi ọwọ́ mẹ́wẹ̀ẹ̀wá jẹun ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn.
English: Eating excessively, eating without self-control, and eating with all ten fingers is not befitting of a human being.

This proverb speaks to the importance of moderation, self-restraint, and proper manners when eating, suggesting that gluttony and poor table manners are undignified behaviors that diminish one's humanity.

yoruba: Òkùnkùn ò mẹni ọ̀wọ̀; ó dÍfá fún “Ìwọ́ tá nìyẹn”?
gold: Darkness does not know who deserves deference; it consulted the oracle Ifá for “Who might you be?”
gen:
The translation of the Yoruba proverb "Òkùnkùn ò mẹni ọ̀wọ̀; ó dÍfá fún 'Ìwọ́ tá nìyẹn'?" to English would be:

"Darkness does not respect anyone; it consults Ifa for 'Is that you?'"

This proverb speaks to how darkness makes everyone equal - in the dark, you cannot recognize even those who would normally command respect, leading to situations where people have to ask "Is that you?" when encountering others.

yoruba: Bí ayá bá mojú ọkọ, alárìnnà a yẹsẹ̀.
gold: When the wife has got to know the husband, the marriage broker makes way.
gen:
Yoruba: Bí ayá bá mojú ọkọ, alárìnnà a yẹsẹ̀.
English: If a wife knows her husband's ways (or understands her husband well), an intruder/meddler will have to step aside.

The proverb suggests that when a wife truly understands her husband or is familiar with his character, outsiders who try to interfere in their relationship will have no place or influence.

yoruba: Ẹni à ńgbé gẹ̀gẹ̀ ni yó ba ara-a rẹ̀ jẹ́.
gold: It is the person who is revered that will disgrace himself or herself.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹni à ńgbé gẹ̀gẹ̀ ni yó ba ara-a rẹ̀ jẹ́.
English: The person we are carrying gently is the one who will harm himself.

This proverb suggests that sometimes when we are trying to help or support someone with care and gentleness, that person may end up causing their own downfall or acting against their own interests.

yoruba: Tẹ̀tẹ̀ kì í tẹ́.
gold: Spinach is never disgraced.
gen:
Looking at this Yoruba proverb:

Yoruba: Tẹ̀tẹ̀ kì í tẹ́.
English: A leprosy patient does not hesitate/delay.

This proverb refers to someone with leprosy (tẹ̀tẹ̀) who doesn't delay or hesitate (tẹ́) - suggesting that people facing serious difficulties or ailments act with urgency. It can be used to convey that those in desperate situations don't have the luxury of delay or hesitation.

yoruba: Ẹní bá dẹ ojú-u rẹ̀ sílẹ̀ á rímú-u rẹ̀.
gold: Whoever gazes downwards with will see his or her nose.
gen:
Yoruba: Ẹní bá dẹ ojú-u rẹ̀ sílẹ̀ á rímú-u rẹ̀.
English: Whoever keeps their eyes on the ground will find their nose.

This proverb suggests that if you remain focused and attentive to what's directly before you (keeping your eyes down), you will find what belongs to you or what you're looking for (your nose). It's about the rewards of focus, patience, and awareness of one's immediate surroundings.

yoruba: Onígẹ̀gẹ́ fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ dọ́pọ̀; onílẹ̀kẹ̀ ìbá gbowo, ko rọ́rùn fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ so.
gold: The person with goitre offers a ridiculously low price for beads; were the beads seller to accept her offer she would have no neck to string the beads around.
gen:
English: The person with neck beads threaded them together; if the person with waist beads had money, it's not difficult to thread waist beads.

This proverb suggests that a person who has accomplished something (threading neck beads) makes it look easy, while implying that others (like those who wear waist beads) could do similar things if they had the resources (money). It speaks to how having means makes tasks easier, and how we shouldn't judge others' lack of accomplishment without considering their constraints.

yoruba: Bí a bá ti mọ là ńdé; a-láì-lẹ́ṣin kì í dé wọ̀nwọ̀n.
gold: One arrives according to one's worth; a horseless person does not arrive with the noise of hoofs and stirrups.
gen:
To translate this Yoruba proverb:

Yoruba: Bí a bá ti mọ là ńdé; a-láì-lẹ́ṣin kì í dé wọ̀nwọ̀n.
English: One takes action according to one's means; a person without a horse does not arrive in grand style.

The proverb essentially means that people should act within their capabilities or resources. Someone without the means (symbolized by not having a horse) cannot make a grand entrance or live beyond their means.

yoruba: “Mo mọ̀wọ̀n ara-à mi” kì í ṣẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́ èébú.
gold: “I am jealous of my dignity” does not hurl insults at others.
gen:
Yoruba: "Mo mọ̀wọ̀n ara-à mi" kì í ṣẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́ èébú.
English: "I know my limitations" is not an expression of insult.

This proverb suggests that acknowledging one's own limitations is not something shameful or insulting, but rather a sign of wisdom and self-awareness.

yoruba: A kì í bá ọba pàlà kí ọkọ́ ọba má ṣàn-ánni lẹ́sẹ̀.
gold: One does not share a farm boundary with a king without getting one's feet gashed by the king's hoe.
gen:
Yoruba: A kì í bá ọba pàlà kí ọkọ́ ọba má ṣàn-ánni lẹ́sẹ̀.
English: One does not quarrel with the king without being struck by the king's messenger.

(This proverb conveys that there are consequences to challenging authority - if you oppose or quarrel with a ruler, you will face repercussions from those who serve them.)

yoruba: Bí eegbọ́n bá ṣo ayínrín nímú, adìẹ kọ́ ni yó ja.
gold: If a tick clings to a fox's nose, it is not a chicken that will remove it.
gen:
Yoruba: Bí eegbọ́n bá ṣo ayínrín nímú, adìẹ kọ́ ni yó ja.
English: If a senior/elder has sand in their nose, it is not a chicken that will remove it.

This proverb suggests that certain problems or issues of important people (elders) should be handled by appropriate individuals, not by those who lack the capability or status to do so. It speaks to knowing one's place and the appropriate hierarchy for addressing sensitive matters.

yoruba: À-sẹ́-kú làgbàlagbà ńsẹ́ ọ̀ràn.
gold: Denying-until-death is the way a venerable person denies a matter.
gen:
Looking at the pattern of the Yoruba proverbs and their English translations, I can translate this one:

Yoruba: À-sẹ́-kú làgbàlagbà ńsẹ́ ọ̀ràn.
English: The elder handles matters with caution (literally: "until death" or "with death-avoidance" is how an elder handles affairs).

This proverb suggests that elders approach problems or situations carefully and wisely, with a full awareness of potential consequences and a desire to avoid disastrous outcomes.

yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀ ò ti ibìkan mú ẹni; ìyà ò tibìkan jẹ èèyàn; bí o bá rìnrìn òṣì, bí o bá ojú ìṣẹ́ wọ̀lú, igbá-kúgbá ni wọn ó fi bu omi fún ẹ mu.
gold: Destitution does not attach to one at a particular place; suffering does not attack a person at a particular place; if one walks like a wretch into a town, if one looks like a loser when one enters a town, it is with a miserable calabash that the people will offer one water to drink.
gen:
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀ ò ti ibìkan mú ẹni; ìyà ò tibìkan jẹ èèyàn; bí o bá rìnrìn òṣì, bí o bá ojú ìṣẹ́ wọ̀lú, igbá-kúgbá ni wọn ó fi bu omi fún ẹ mu.

English: Poverty does not come from one place; suffering does not afflict a person from one source; if you walk in poverty, if you enter a town with the face of poverty, they will serve you water in a broken calabash.

yoruba: Oòrùn, kó tìẹ wọ̀ ká má bàá Ọlọ́jọ́ wí.
gold: Sun, go set so one does not blame the owner of the day.
gen:
Yoruba: Oòrùn, kó tìẹ wọ̀ ká má bàá Ọlọ́jọ́ wí.
English: Let the sun set so that we don't have to blame the Owner of the day.

This proverb suggests that it's better to let things come to their natural conclusion (like letting the sun set) rather than complaining about or blaming the one in charge (the Owner of the day/God). It conveys patience and acceptance of natural processes rather than resistance.

yoruba: Mo dàgbà mo dàgó, aré ọmọdé ò tán lójúù mi.
gold: I have become old and wise, but childish play has not ceased to appeal to me.
gen:
Yoruba: Mo dàgbà mo dàgó, aré ọmọdé ò tán lójúù mi.
English: I have grown old and tall, but I have not lost sight of the playfulness of children.

The proverb suggests that despite aging and maturing physically, the speaker still appreciates, understands, or remembers what it's like to be a child. It conveys the wisdom of maintaining connection with youthful energy and perspective even as one grows older.

yoruba: Olóbìnrin kan kì í pagbo ìja.
gold: A person who has only  one wife does not form a circle for a fight.
gen:
Based on the pattern of Yoruba proverbs and their English translations you've provided, here's the translation:

Yoruba: Olóbìnrin kan kì í pagbo ìja.
English: A woman does not completely end/resolve a fight.

This proverb suggests that a woman alone cannot fully settle or put an end to a conflict. It likely speaks to traditional gender roles or perspectives on conflict resolution in Yoruba culture.
